I haven't been working quite at the industrial scale that John has :) 
but a here is where work currently stands:

1) Tic Tac Toe -  I created a new player based on the 'Best' player 
described in Derek and Philips paper (originally from elsewhere I 
believe). I initially modified the strategy by making it randomly select 
from the set of available moves at any given point in a game. I have 
taken this further by building a list of available moves sorted by how 
many open lines each can participate in, e.g. the center square can 
participate in up to 4 different lines (horizontal, vertical, and the 
two diagonals), an open line is defined as one that does not yet contain 
any of the opponents pieces. A sort of roulette wheel selection is then 
performed on this list - it is currently heavily weighted towards the 
good moves, but the chance of selecting the best move is not 100%.  This 
strategy is incorportaed into the existing ones of always playing a 
winning move, blocking an opponent winning move, forking and fork 
blocking strategies.

What this does is provide a more varied range of play, that hopefully 
will help evolve more robust players. In fact the weighting described 
above could be adjusted to create anything from very good to very bad 
players, but hopefully they won't be quite as predictable as the current 
set of players - although I am keeping them as part of the evaluation.

This extra player hasn't greatly improved the evolved networks so far, 
although some experimenting with the above startegy is still required.


2) Phased searching - The current plan then is to implement the 'phased 
search' technique discussed on this groups a while ago, and to see if it 
is able evolve better players. Before I do this though I want to 
implement a more simple problem domain, one that is fast to evaluate so 
that experiments can be run a lot faster....


3)OCR - Optical Character Recognition. The plan is to expose a set of 2D 
bitmaps, in turn, to the inputs of an NN. The number of outputs will 
reflect the number of 2D maps in the current set, so that the NN can 
indicate which character it 'thinks' it is looking at by setting the 
appropriate output high. Straightforward and hopefully very fast. Also 
the problem difficulty can be adjusted by changing the set size, the 
data in the sets and the dimensions of each character.  Using such a 
scheme allows us to very rapidly increase the input/output space - which 
we know is going to cause NEAT difficulties. I can then experiment on 
this domain with phased searching switched on to see if it improves the 
NNs we can generate.


I was also thinking that I could provide a set of shapes in various 
orientations and evolve NNs that are able to pick out the same shape in 
it's different orientations. Perhaps some background reading is in order 
here as there are probably loads of other variations on these schemes 
that I /could/ do.

Colin
